DOC.HEAD: Hunt Launched for Hundreds of Previously Unknown War Criminals
DOC.TEXT: Nazi hunters are searching for hundreds of newly identified Lithuanian war crimes suspects believed hiding in the United States, Canada, Australia and Britain, the Simon Wiesenthal Center said Tuesday. The names are listed in files of testimony from Jewish survivors in Soviet Lithuania given three months ago to the Yad Vashem archives in Jerusalem, which is in charge of documenting the slayings of 6 million Jews during World War II by Nazi Germany. The records were kept secret for more than four decades by an elderly Lithuanian survivor, Leibl Kuniuchovsky, who now lives in Sunrise, Fla., said Efraim Zuroff, director of the Israeli office of the Los Angeles-based center known for tracking down Nazi suspects. ``This material has enormous significance. Based on our past experience this can lead us to numerous Nazi war criminals now living in the United States, Canada, Australia and the United Kingdom,'' Zuroff said. He said the approximately 1,300 names on the list are Lithuanians who collaborated with the Nazis during 1941-42, when most mass slayings of Jews took place in the Baltic republic. More than 200,000 Jews are believed to have been murdered by the Nazis in Lithuania. Lithuania was a center of Jewish culture in Eastern Europe in the 18th and 19th centuries and a nesting ground for the Zionist ideology that led to the creation of Israel. The Jewish community there numbered 1.5 million at the turn of the century and only 26,000 after World War II. Kuniuchovsky, a survivor of the Jewish ghetto in the city of Kovno, took the testimony from refugees after the war on behalf of historical commissions set up by the Allies in displaced persons camps in West Germany, Zuroff said. His records are valuable because they provide rare accounts from the few Jews who survived the mass slayings that took place in isolated towns and villages, Zuroff said in an interview. He said the 1,300 names were gathered from 1,683 pages of testimony that Kuniuchovsky took from survivors in 171 towns and villages. Hundreds of the suspects were known to be alive, Zuroff added. He declined to give names of the suspects, suggesting this could harm efforts to seek them out for prosecution. ``The majority were previously unknown to us,'' he said, noting the earlier testimony was sketchy about slayings in many isolated areas because survivors were few and investigators were unable to find them in later years. Zuroff said the Wiesenthal Center is tracking the suspects through its four branches in the United States, one in Toronto, and other agencies. The center is named for founder Simon Wiesenthal, 80, an Austrian-born concentration camp survivor who has devoted much of his life to hunting down Nazi war criminals and documenting the Holocaust. In addition to new suspects' names, Kuniuchovsky's file also contains surprising information about the numbers of Lithuanians involved in the killings, Zuroff said. ``It is shocking to see such a big role was played by the intelligentsia,'' Zuroff added. ``We're talking about school teachers, educated people'' who belonged to vigilante groups or helped local police carry out killings. Zuroff also said he hoped legislation adopted in the past two years in Canada and Australia, allowing prosecution of crimes committed overseas, would make it easier to hunt and prosecute the Lithuanian suspects.
